title: Can we prove that everything in the universe must follow the laws of physics? Is it possible that something might disobey the laws of physics? - Quora

response.answer_text: Of course you can’t actually prove anything in science. All scientific theories are essentially provisional and open to revision when/if contradictory evidence comes to light. Indeed a good definition of what lies outside of science is any system which does not allow for disproof. However, that said, what science does assume is that the universe is ruled by one set of laws. However, that does not, in principle mean that the “laws” (which I quote as there are no such things as laws of physics; there are just theories) which we have derived so far are necessarily the last word in the matter. It might just be that the “laws” we have derived so far are special in the sense they only apply in that specific form to “our” part of the universe at this point in time. However, what we would then do is seek to derive a more generalised form of theory whereby “our” set of laws is simply a sub-set. On example of this was the “physical law” which pertained as to spatial geometry. Inherent in Newton’s theory of gravitation was that space was Euclidean and that time progressed at the same rate for all objects. That made perfect sense from the experiments and observations that we possible at the time. It explained, within the limits of the technology available at the time, the motion of the planets and moons. It was thus a perfectly reasonable definition of a physical theory or law. However, doubts started creeping in, firstly with the observation that the measured speed of light appeared to be constant. Then there were discrepancies with the orbit of Mercury that couldn’t be explained using Newton’s theory of gravity. Eventually these discrepancies were resolved with Einstein’s Special and General Theory of Relativity respectively. What we found was that the apparent “laws” of physics that worked very well locally (and sill do for most purpose) of Newton’s theories of gravity and motion were simply a special case (or approximation) of those more generalised theories. So it might be with the current “laws” (or theories) of physics that we have derived to date. Perhaps these are just a local approximation to a more general set of “laws” which apply across the wider universe. However, before going too far into the idea that what we have derived is “just” a special case of wider rules, I would say that the sciences of astrophysics and cosmology are seeking to look to see whether the theories we have devised to date are generalisable to the whole universe. For example, do they apply to the time just after the “big bang” and can they explain the phenomenon we see by (effectively) looking back in time? Can the laws explain phenomena such as pulsars and quasars? Can it explain the motion of galaxies? Is this all compatible with the “standard model” of quantum mechanics? Are our observations consistent with the speed of light always being constant? These investigations have, indeed, indicated that our current physical theories are incomplete. For example, there is that mystery of the apparent missing mass in the universe which astrophysicists call “dark matter”. Then there’s the apparent accelerating expansion of the universe, the cause of which has been labelled as “dark energy”. These don’t fit into the current accepted theories (or “laws”) of physics, although there are many suggestions. However, the principle remains that physics will still seek to produce a single set of theories (or, ideally, one “grand unified theory”) which can “explain” (strictly speaking, model mathematically) all these phenomena. So there will be “one law to rule them all”, to slighly paraphrase Tolkein. nb. this also leads into theories of parallel universes which (in one incarnation at least) broadly asks whether the rules that apparently apply in our universe are the only possible ones or might there be any number (indeed an infinity) of self-consistent universes, all acted out according to their own rules of existence. To what extent this law that essentially states all possible self consistent universes must, in some sense, exist is actually a common law, who knows?

It is an assumption of science that the universe is lawful. This means that it is possible to do science. If the universe was only a lot a random stuff happening science wouldn’t work. Science looks at the evidence and find things that are happen consistently. If there was just random stuff happening this would not work. (It’s a bit hard to see how a universe of random stuff happening would work either.) Scientists come up with ideas of how something works then they - and others - check it out against existing and new evidence. If the idea doesn’t fit the evidence it is either thrown away or modified. That way scientific laws improve over time, with better ideas and more evidence. On the other hand, we can’t prove any law of physics. Proof is actually not a part of science. Proof is something we get in closed systems, in particular in mathematics. We simply don’t have the capability to check that a law of physics applies everywhere in the observable universe so the universe is not a closed system. In a sense, the laws of physics are guesses. Initially there might not be much evidence, but as the evidence stacks up, you reach a point where it is crazy to believe otherwise. Science relies on evidence, not proof. We can rule things out with contrary evidence, but we can’t rule them in. For example, we believe that every electron in the universe has the same rest mass. We certainly can’t weigh each one individually. That’s just how it is. We do know that if the masses were different in different parts of the universe, atomic energies and chemistry would be different in different places, and we would see this in radiation received from distant galaxies. We don’t. In fact, the mass of an electron is so well tested and correlates so well with a bunch of other physics, that if some evidence for electrons with a different mass turned up, physicists would immediately look for other explanations. I’d bet they’d find that the data was wrong too. The mass of an electron is “rock solid” physics. Rock solid science, but not proven. So, we simply cannot prove that the laws of physics apply everywhere. Science assumes that we can get to the correct universal laws with enough thinking and testing, but there’s no absolute proof. But proof or not, the program does seem to be working.

Although it seems like a logical conclusion to jump to, I would not adhere to Physics. Because “Physics” is not defined. If you mean “Physics” as something that Universe follows then yeah, By the definition it is proved that everything in the universe must follow the laws of physics. But if you mean “Physics” as a set of rules and knowledge that we have developed, then NO. There’s only one thing that scientists around us are looking for. New things that disobey our pre formed theories. Science as we know is made by breaking theories and making new ones as we get the evidence in the process. So, as long as we discover the Ultimate truths of the Universe and become gods we can’t say that everything in the Universe follows known physics. By the way, we will never find out every single truth about Universe? Why you ask?.. Because of Gödel's incompleteness theorems. If I had to explain it to a lay man, I would say that every law of physics has its own assumptions. You would have to prove those assumptions to be sure that your laws are laws. Now to prove those assumptions you would have to make further assumptions ( postulates ). This cycle would continue for ever because there is something that you always donot know in this universe. It is an assumption that gets checked all the time. In fact it is rather surprising that the “laws” of physics are so uniform across the entire cosmos as far as we can tell. It is entirely possible that CP violation, for instance, might have the opposite sign in different regions; people have written papers on the energy stored in the resulting “domain walls”, but no such phenomenon has ever been detected unambiguously. (Which is a good reason to go looking for one — instant Nobel! ;-) But here’s the thing: suppose we find a region where some “law” is different; the “law” instantly adapts to take the region-dependence into account! To take a particularly unlikely example, if we found a region X where Newton’s “universal” gravitational constant was G′=0.66741×10−10G′=0.66741×10−10 m33 kg−1−1 s−2−2 instead of G=0.66742×10−10G=0.66742×10−10 m33 kg−1−1 s−2−2, Newton’s Law of Universal Gravitation would immediately become Newton’s Revised Law of Regional Gravitation: “Use G except in region X; there, use G’.” That may sound weaselly to a lawyer, but the nice thing about Laws of Physics is that we don’t just make them up; they are dictated to us by the facts. Therefore they are instantly revisable when new facts present themselves. That’s how science is supposed to progress. As I said, the surprising thing is that this happens so rarely!

We do not need to prove that the universe must follow the laws because the laws are the way that the universe behaves per-definition. It is a typical layperson mistake to take the names in science literally and this question is a good example of that. The word “law” must not be taken literally, that is just a name which does not imply or prove anything about the nature of the laws of physics. The word “law” does not mean for example that the concepts “obey” and “follow” apply here. The laws of physics are a description of how things “are”, how things behave and how things can behave. This is not a matter of obeying or following. Things are things and cannot decide to be not things anymore, unless this kind of shape shifting is part of their “thingy-ness” which would make that shape-shifting part of the law that describes them.

Surely you must realize that the word “law” in the context of physics is very far from the meaning of that word in ordinary everyday language. Physics “laws” are explanations, not limitations on behavior as is meant normally by the same word. The 1st “law” of thermodynamics - aka conservation of energy - explains energy cannot be created or destroyed, only change in form. This is not a legal definition, it is nothing to be “obeyed” or “disobeyed”. It’s a general principle which guides physicists when they study physical reality, that is all it is. Regarding the word “prove” you must be thinking of math proofs. There is no such thing in science as proof. In science there is testing, verifying and falsifying.

The goals of physics include a full description of all the material world. So yes everything in the universe does follow the laws of physics. However the laws that we write down are just our best assessment of what those laws actually are. We have up to now been very lucky that our abilities to explain what we observe has not been far behind our observations. Of course perhaps this is the other way around and our observations have not been able to keep up with the laws that we have written and it may be just a matter of time before experimenters are successful at finding holes in our theories! For me as long as science keeps making things better for humanity (and perhaps other beings) then a step at a time is ok.

It is possible to prove that “something might disobey the Laws of Physics”. More precisely, if the Laws of Physics are written in English or some similar language then taken all together either they are self-contradictory or there is some situation that they do not cover. This remains true however the Laws of Physics are rewritten as long as they are written in a language with a finite character set and include basic arithmetic. The proof relies on Kurt Godel’s Incompleteness Theorem. Godel provided a mathematical proof which is equivalent to the following: “Any theory written in a finite character set and including basic arithmetic is either inconsistent or incomplete.” “Theory” means a set of statements regarded as axiomatically true and rules for generating other true statements from them. “Inconsistent” means there is a statement that the theory calls both true and not true “Incomplete” means there is some statement whose truth is not determined by the theory

The universe does not have to follow the laws of physics. The laws of physics were introduced by man to explain the best way they can how the universe appears to be. With the information we have of the universe at the moment, this is what we believe to be true.

Well, basically, if we find something that “breaks the laws”, it means we need to amend or change the laws. The laws were discovered by observing how things work…and, if a new condition is found that we need more observations for, we simply do more observations and then try to come up with some possible explanations for this new observation. We then test the new explanation to see if it really works, and, if not, toss it and try a new one, etc. Sometimes we find the law was not broken, but that it just did not apply to the new situation, etc.
